verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:4
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:5
verses.text: Let us likewise deal kindly, let us persuade our adversaries of that which is to their profit, "let us worship and lament before the Lord our Maker".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:6
verses.text: For we would not overthrow, but rather heal; we lay no ambush for them, but warn them as in duty bound.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:7
verses.text: Kindliness often bends those whom neither force nor argument will avail to overcome.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:8
verses.text: Again, our Lord cured with oil and wine the man who, going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, fell among thieves; having forborne to treat him with the harsh remedies of the Law or the sternness of Prophecy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:10
verses.text: To Him, therefore, let all come who would be made whole.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:11
verses.text: Let them receive the medicine which He hath brought down from His Father and made in heaven, preparing it of the juices of those celestial fruits that wither not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:12
verses.text: This is of no earthly growth, for nature nowhere possesseth this compound.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:13
verses.text: Of wondrous purpose took He our flesh, to the end that He might show that the law of the flesh had been subjected to the law of the mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:14
verses.text: He was incarnate, that He, the Teacher of men, might overcome as man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:15
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:16
verses.text: Of what profit would it have been to me, had He, as God, bared the arm of His power, and only displayed His Godhead inviolate? Why should He take human nature upon Him, but to suffer Himself to be tempted under the conditions of my nature and my weakness? It was right that He should be tempted, that He should suffer with me, to the end that I might know how to conquer when tempted, how  to escape when hard pressed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:17
verses.text: He overcame by force of continence, of contempt of riches, of faith; He trampled upon ambition, fled from intemperance, bade wantonness be far from Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:19
verses.text: This medicine Peter beheld, and left His nets, that is to say, the instruments and security of gain, renouncing the lust of the flesh as a leaky ship, that receives the bilge, as it were, of multitudinous passions.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:20
verses.text: Truly a mighty remedy, that not only removed the scar of an old wound, but even cut the root and source of passion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:21
verses.text: O Faith, richer than all treasure-houses; O excellent remedy, healing our wounds and sins!  93.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:22
verses.text: Let us bethink ourselves of the profitableness of right belief.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:23
verses.text: It is profitable to me to know that for my sake Christ bore my infirmities, submitted to the affections of my body, that for me, that is to say, for every man, He was made sin, and a curse, that for me and in me was He humbled and made subject, that for me He is the Lamb, the Vine, the Rock, the Servant, the Son of an handmaid, knowing not the day of judgment, for my sake ignorant of the day and the hour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:24
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:25
verses.text: For how could He, Who hath made days and times, be ignorant of the day? How could He not know the day, Who hath declared both the season of Judgment to come, and the cause? A curse, then, He was made not in respect of His Godhead, but of His flesh; for it is written: "Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:26
verses.text: In and after the flesh, therefore, He hung, and for this cause He, Who bore our curses, became a curse.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:27
verses.text: He wept that thou, man, mightest not weep long.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:28
verses.text: He endured insult, that thou mightest not grieve over the wrong done to thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:30
verses.text: A glorious remedy—to have consolation of Christ! For He bore these things with surpassing patience for our sakes—and we forsooth cannot bear them with common patience for the glory of His Name! Who may not learn to forgive, when assailed, seeing that Christ, even on the Cross, prayed,—yea, for them that persecuted Him? See you not that those weaknesses, as you please to call them, of Christ's are your strength? Why question Him in the matter of remedies for us? His tears wash us, His weeping cleanses us,—and there is strength in this doubt, at least, that if you begin to doubt, you will despair.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:31
verses.text: The greater the insult, the greater is the gratitude due.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:32
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:33
verses.text: Even in the very hour of mockery and insult, acknowledge His Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:34
verses.text: He hung upon the Cross, and all the elements did Him homage.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:35
verses.text: The sun withdrew his rays, the daylight vanished, darkness came down and covered the land, the earth trembled; yet He Who hung there trembled not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:36
verses.text: What was it that these signs betokened, but reverence for the Creator? That He hangs upon the Cross—this, thou Arian, thou regardest; that He gives the kingdom of God—this, thou regardest not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:37
verses.text: That He tasted of death, thou readest, but that He also invited the robber into paradise, to this thou givest no heed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:38
verses.text: Thou dost gaze at the women weeping by the tomb, but not upon the angels keeping watch by it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:39
verses.text: What He said, thou readest: what He did, thou dost not read.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:40
verses.text: Thou sayest that the Lord said to the Canaanitish woman: "I am not sent, but to the lost sheep of the house of Israel," thou dost not say that He did what He was besought by her to do.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:41
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:42
verses.text: Thou shouldst hereby understand that His being "sent" means not that He was compelled, at the command of another, but that He acted, of free will, according to His own judgment, otherwise thou dost accuse Him of despising His Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:43
verses.text: For if, according to thine expounding, Christ had come into Jewry, as one executing the Father's commands, to relieve the inhabitants of Jewry, and none besides, and yet before that was accomplished, set free the Canaanitish woman's daughter from her complaint, surely He was not only the executor of another's instruction, but was free to exercise His own judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:44
verses.text: But where there is freedom to act as one will, there can be no transgressing the terms of one's mission.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:45
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:46
verses.text: Fear not that the Son's act displeased the Father, seeing that the Son Himself  saith: "Whatsoever things are His good pleasure, I do always," and "The works that I do, He Himself doeth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:47
verses.text: How, then, could the Father be displeased with that which He Himself did through the Son? For it is One God, Who, as it is written, "hath justified circumcision in consequence of faith, and uncircumcision through faith".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:48
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:49
verses.text: Read all the Scriptures, mark all diligently, you will then find that Christ so manifested Himself that God might be discerned in man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 11:50
verses.text: Misunderstand not maliciously the Son's exultation in the Father, when you hear the Father declaring His pleasure in the Son.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:2
verses.text: Do the Catholics or the Arians take the better course to assure themselves of the favour of Christ as their Judge? An objection grounded on Ps.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:3
verses.text: cx.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:4
verses.text: 1 is disposed of, it being shown that when the Son is invited by the Father to sit at His right hand, no subjection is intended to be signified—nor yet any preferment, in that the Son sits at the Father's right hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:5
verses.text: The truth of the Trinity of Persons in God, and of the Unity of their Nature, is shown to be proved by the angelic Trisagion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:7
verses.text: Howbeit, if our adversaries cannot be turned by kindness, let us summon them before the Judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:8
verses.text: To what Judge, then, shall we go? Surely to Him Who hath the Judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:9
verses.text: To the Father, then? Nay, but "the Father judgeth no man, for He hath given all judgment to the Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:10
verses.text: He hath given, that is to say, not as of largess, but in the act of generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:11
verses.text: See, then, how unwilling He was that thou shouldst dishonour His Son—even so that He gave Him to be thy Judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:12
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:13
verses.text: Let us see, then, before the judgment which hath the better cause, thou or I? Surely it is the care of a prudent party to a suit to gain first the favourable regard of the judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:14
verses.text: Thou dost honour man,—dost thou not honour God? Which of the two, I ask, wins the favour of the magistrate—respect or contempt? Suppose that I am in error—as I certainly am not: is Christ displeased with the honour shown Him? We are all sinners—who, then, will deserve forgiveness, he who renders worship, or he who displays insolence?  102.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:15
verses.text: If reasoning move thee not, at least let the plain aspect of the judgment move thee! Raise thine eyes to the Judge, see Who it is that is seated, with Whom He is seated, and where.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:16
verses.text: Christ sitteth at the right hand of the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:17
verses.text: If with thine eyes thou canst not perceive this, hear the words of the prophet: "The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit Thou on My right hand".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:18
verses.text: The Son, therefore, sitteth at the right hand of the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:19
verses.text: Tell me now, thou who holdest that the things of God are to be judged of from the things of this world—say whether thou thinkest Him Who sits at the right hand to be lower? Is it any dishonour to the Father that He sits at the Son's left hand? The Father honours the Son, and thou makest it to be insult! The Father would have this invitation to be a sign of love and esteem, and thou wouldst make it an overlord's command! Christ hath risen from the dead, and sitteth at the right hand of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:20
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:21
verses.text: "But," you object, "the Father said".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:22
verses.text: Good, hear now a passage where the Father doth not speak, and the Son prophesies: "Hereafter ye shall see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of power".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:23
verses.text: This He said with regard to taking back to Himself His body—to Him the Father said: "Sit Thou at My right hand".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:24
verses.text: If indeed you ask of the eternal abode of the Godhead, He said—when Pilate asked Him whether He were the King of the Jews—"For this I was born".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:25
verses.text: And so indeed the Apostle shows that it is good for us to believe that Christ sitteth at the right hand of God, not by command, nor of any boon, but as God's most dearly beloved Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:26
verses.text: For it is written for you: "Seek the things that are above, where Christ is, sitting at the right hand of God; savour the things that are above".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:27
verses.text: This is to savour the things that be above—to believe that Christ, in His sitting, does not obey as one who receives a command, but is honoured as the well-beloved Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:28
verses.text: It is with regard, then, to Christ's Body that the Father saith: "Sit Thou at My right hand, until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:30
verses.text: If, again, you seek to pervert the sense of these words, "I will make Thine enemies Thy footstool," I answer that the Father also bringeth to the Son such as the Son raiseth up and quickeneth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:31
verses.text: For "No man," saith Christ, "can come to Me, except the Father, Which hath sent Me, draw him, and I will raise him up at the last day".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:32
verses.text: And you say that the Son of God is subject  by reason of weakness—the Son, to Whom the Father bringeth men that He may raise them up in the last day.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:33
verses.text: Seemeth this in your eyes to be subjection, I pray you, where the kingdom is prepared for the Father, and the Father bringeth to the Son and there is no place for perversion of words, since the Son giveth the kingdom to the Father, and none is preferred before Him? For inasmuch as the Father rendereth to the Son, and the Son, again, to the Father, here are plain proofs of love and regard: seeing that They so render, the One to the Other, that neither He Who receiveth obtaineth as it were what was another's, nor He That rendereth loseth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:34
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:35
verses.text: Moreover, the sitting at the right hand is no preferment, nor doth that at the left hand betoken dishonour, for there are no degrees in the Godhead, Which is bound by no limits of space or time, which are the weights and measures of our puny human minds.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:36
verses.text: There is no difference of love, nothing that divideth the Unity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:37
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:38
verses.text: But wherefore roam so far afield? Thou hast looked upon all around thee, thou hast seen the Judge, thou hast remarked the angels proclaiming Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:39
verses.text: They praise, and thou revilest Him! Dominations and powers fall down before Him—thou speakest evil of His Name! All His Saints adore Him, but the Son of God adores not, nor the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:40
verses.text: The seraphim say: "Holy, Holy, Holy!"  107.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:41
verses.text: What meaneth this threefold utterance of the same name "Holy"? If thrice repeated, why is it but one act of praise? If one act of praise, why a threefold repetition? Why the threefold repetition, unless that the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit are one in holiness? The seraph spake the name, not once, lest he should exclude the Son; not twice, lest he should pass by the Holy Spirit; not four times, lest he should conjoin created beings [in the praise of the Creator].

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:42
verses.text: Furthermore, to show that the Godhead of the Trinity is One, he, after the threefold "Holy," added in the singular number "the Lord God of Sabaoth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:43
verses.text: Holy, therefore, is the Father, holy the Son, holy likewise the Spirit of God, and therefore is the Trinity adored, but adores not, and is praised, but praises not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 12:44
verses.text: As for me, I will rather believe as the seraphim, and adore after the manner of all the principalities and powers of heaven.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:2
verses.text: The wicked and dishonourable opinions held by Arians, Sabellians, and Manichaeans as concerning their Judge are shortly refuted.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:3
verses.text: Christ's remonstrances regarding the rest of His adversaries being set forth, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:4
verses.text: Ambrose expresses a hope of milder judgment for himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:6
verses.text: Let us proceed, then, with your accusations, and see how you gain the favour of your Judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:7
verses.text: Speak now, speak, I say, and tell Him: "I consider Thee, O Christ, to be unlike Thy Father;" and He will answer: "Mark, if thou canst, mark, I say, and tell Me wherein thou holdest Me to differ".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:8
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:9
verses.text: Say again: "I judge Thee to be a created being;" and Christ will reply: "If the witness of two men is true, oughtest thou not to have believed both Me and My Father, Who hath called Me His Son?"  110.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:10
verses.text: Then you will say: "I deny Thy [perfect] goodness;" and He will answer: "Be it unto thee according to thy faith; so will I not be good to thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:12
verses.text: "That Thou art Almighty, I hold not;" and He will answer, in turn: "Then can I not forgive thee thy sins".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:14
verses.text: "Thou art a subject being".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:15
verses.text: Whereto He will reply: "Why, then, dost thou seek freedom and pardon of Him Whom thou thinkest to be subject as a slave?"  113.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:16
verses.text: I see your accusation halt here.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:17
verses.text: I press you not, forasmuch as I myself know my own sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:18
verses.text: I grudge you not pardon, for I myself would obtain indulgence, but I would know the object of your prayers.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:19
verses.text: Look, then, whilst I recite before the Judge your desires.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:20
verses.text: I betray not your sins, but look to behold your prayers and wishes set forth in their order.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:21
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:22
verses.text: Speak, therefore, those desires, which all alike would have granted to them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:23
verses.text: "Lord, make me in the image of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:24
verses.text: Whereto He will answer: "In what image? The image which thou hast denied?"  115.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:25
verses.text: "Make me incorruptible".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:26
verses.text: Surely His reply will be: "How can I make thee incorruptible, I, Whom thou callest a created being, and so wouldst make out to be corruptible? The dead shall rise purified from corruption—dost thou call Him corruptible Whom thou seest to be God?"  116.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:27
verses.text: "Be good to me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:28
verses.text: "Why dost thou ask what thou hast denied [to Me]? I would have had thee to be good, and I said 'Be ye holy, for I Myself am holy,'  and thou settest thyself to deny that I am good? Dost thou then look for forgiveness of sins? Nay, none can forgive sins, but God alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:29
verses.text: Seeing, then, that to thee I am not the true and only God, I cannot by any means forgive thee thy sins".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:30
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:31
verses.text: Thus let the followers of Arius and Photinus speak.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:32
verses.text: "I deny Thy Godhead".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:33
verses.text: To whom the Lord will make answer: "'The fool hath said in his heart: There is no God' Of whom, think you, is this said?—of Jew or Gentile, or of the devil.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:34
verses.text: Whosoever he be of whom it is said, O disciple of Photinus, he is more to be borne with, who held his peace; thou, nevertheless, hast dared to lift up thy voice to utter it, that thou mightest be proved more foolish than the fool.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:35
verses.text: Thou deniest My Godhead, whereas I said, 'Ye are gods, and ye are all the children of the Most Highest?' And thou deniest Him to be God, Whose godlike works thou seest around thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:36
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:37
verses.text: Let the Sabellian speak in his turn.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:38
verses.text: "I consider Thee, by Thyself, to be at once Father and Son and Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:39
verses.text: To whom the Lord: "Thou hearest neither the Father nor the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:40
verses.text: Is there any doubt on this matter? The Scripture itself teaches thee that it is the Father Who giveth over the judgment, and the Son Who judges.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:41
verses.text: Thou hast not given ear to My words: 'I am not alone, but I and the Father, Who sent Me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:42
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:43
verses.text: Now let the Manichaean have his word.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:44
verses.text: "I hold that the devil is the creator of our flesh".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:45
verses.text: The Lord will answer him: "What, then, doest thou in the heavenly places? Depart, go thy way to thy creator.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:46
verses.text: 'My will is that they be with Me, whom my Father hath given Me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:47
verses.text: ' Thou, Manichaean, holdest thyself for a creature of the devil; hasten, then, to his abode, the place of fire and brimstone, where the fire thereof is not quenched, lest ever the punishment have an end".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:48
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:49
verses.text: I set aside other heretical—not persons, but portents.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:50
verses.text: What manner of judgment awaits them, what shall be the form of their sentence? To all these He will, indeed, reply, rather in sorrow than in anger: "O My people, what have I done unto thee, wherein have I vexed thee? Did I not bring thee up out of Egypt, and lead thee out of the house of bondage into liberty?"  121.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:51
verses.text: But it is not enough to have brought us out of Egypt into freedom, and to have saved us from the house of bondage: a greater boon than this, Thou hast given Thyself for us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:52
verses.text: Thou wilt say then: "Have I not borne all your sufferings? Have I not given My Body for you? Have I not sought death, which had no part in My Godhead, but was necessary for your redemption? Are these the thanks I am to receive? Is it this that My Blood hath gained, even as I spake in times past by the mouth of the prophet: 'What profit is there in My Blood, for that I have gone down to corruption?' Is this the profit, that you should wickedly deny Me—you, for whom I endured those things?"  122.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:53
verses.text: As for me, Lord Jesu, though I am conscious within myself of great sin, yet will I say: "I have not denied Thee; Thou mayest pardon the infirmity of my flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:54
verses.text: My transgression I confess; my sin I deny not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:55
verses.text: If Thou wilt Thou canst make me clean.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:56
verses.text: For this saying, the leper obtained his request.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:57
verses.text: Enter not, I pray, into judgment with Thy servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 13:58
verses.text: I ask, not that Thou mayest judge, but that Thou mayest forgive".

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:2
verses.text: The sentence of the Judge is set forth, the counterpleas of the opposers are considered, and the finality of the sentence, from which there is no appeal, proved.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:3
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:4
verses.text: What verdict do we look for from Christ? That do I know.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:5
verses.text: Do I say, what verdict will He give? Nay, He hath already pronounced sentence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:6
verses.text: We have it in our hands.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:7
verses.text: "Let all," saith He, "honour the Son, even as they honour the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:8
verses.text: He that honoureth not the Son, honoureth not the Father, Who hath sent Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:10
verses.text: If the sentence please you not, appeal to the Father, cancel the judgment that the Father hath given.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:11
verses.text: Say that He hath a Son Who is unlike Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:12
verses.text: He will reply: "Then have I lied, I, Who said to the Son, 'Let us make man in Our image and likeness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:14
verses.text: Tell the Father that He hath created  the Son, and He will answer: "Why, then, hast thou worshipped One Whom thou thoughtest to be a created being?"  126.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:15
verses.text: Tell Him that He hath begotten a Son Who is inferior to Himself, and He will reply: "Compare Us, and let Us see".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:16
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:17
verses.text: Tell Him that you owed no credence to the Son, whereto He will answer: "Did I not say to thee, 'This is My well-beloved Son, in Whom I am well pleased: hear ye Him'?" What mean these words "hear ye Him," if not "Hear Him when He saith: 'All things that the Father hath are Mine'"? This did the apostles hear, even as it is written: "And they fell upon their faces, and were greatly afraid".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:18
verses.text: If they who confessed Him fell to the earth, what shall they do who have denied Him? But Jesus laid His hand upon His apostles, and raised them up—you He will suffer to lie prone, that ye may see not the glory ye have denied.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:19
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 14:20
verses.text: Let us look to it, then, forasmuch as whom the Son condemneth, the Father condemneth also, and therefore let us honour the Son, even as we honour the Father, that by the Son we may be able to come to the Father.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:3
verses.text: Ambrose deprecates any praise of his own merits: in any case, the Faith is sufficiently defended by the authoritative support of holy Scripture, to whose voice the Arians, stubborn as the Jews, are deaf.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:4
verses.text: He prays that they may be moved to love the truth; meanwhile, they are to be avoided, as heretics and enemies of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:6
verses.text: These arguments, your Majesty, I have set forth, briefly and summarily, in the rough, rather than in any form of full explanation and exact order.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:7
verses.text: If indeed the Arians regard them as imperfect and unfinished, I indeed confess that they are scarce even begun; if they think that there be any still to be brought forward, I allow that there be well-nigh all; for whereas the unbelievers are in uttermost need of arguments, the faithful have enough and to spare.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:8
verses.text: Indeed, Peter's single confession was abundant to warrant faith in Christ: "Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God;" for it is enough to know His Divine Generation, without division or diminution, being neither derivation nor creation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:10
verses.text: This, indeed, is declared in the books of Holy Writ, one and all, and yet is still doubted by misbelievers: "For," as it is written, "the heart of this people is become gross, and with their ears they have been dull of hearing, and their eyes have they darkened, lest ever they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand in their heart".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:11
verses.text: For, like the Jews, the Arians' wont is to stop their ears, or make an uproar, as often as the Word of salvation is heard.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:12
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:13
verses.text: And what wonder, if unbelievers doubt the word of man, when they refuse to believe the Word of God? The Son of God, as you will find it written in the Gospel, said: "Father, glorify Thy Name," and from heaven was heard the voice of the Father, saying: "I have both glorified it, and again will glorify".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:14
verses.text: These words the unbelievers heard, but believed not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:15
verses.text: The Son spake, the Father answered, and the Jews said: "A peal of thunder answered Him;" others said: "An angel spake to Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:16
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:17
verses.text: Paul, moreover, as it is written in the Acts of the Apostles, when by the Voice of Christ he received the call of grace, several companions journeying with him at the same time, alone said that he had heard Christ's Voice.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:18
verses.text: Thus, your sacred Majesty, he who believes, hears—and he hears, that he may believe, whilst he who believes not, hears not, nay, he will not, he cannot hear, lest he should believe!  133.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:19
verses.text: As for me, indeed, would that they might have a will to hear, that they might believe—to hear with true love and meekness, as men seeking what is true, and not assailing all truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:20
verses.text: For it is written that we pay no heed to "endless fables and genealogies, which do rather raise disputes than set forward the godly edification, which is in faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:21
verses.text: But the aim of the charge is love from a pure heart, and a good conscience, and faith unfeigned, whence some have erred and betaken themselves to empty babbling, desirous of being teachers  of the law, without understanding the words they say, nor the things whereof they speak with assurance".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:22
verses.text: In another place also the same Apostle saith: "But foolish and ignorant questionings do thou avoid".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:24
verses.text: Such men, who sow disputes—that is to say, heretics—the Apostle bids us leave alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:25
verses.text: Of them he says in yet another place, that "certain shall depart from the faith, giving heed to deceitful spirits, and the doctrines of devils".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:26
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:27
verses.text: John, likewise, saith that heretics are Antichrists, plainly marking out the Arians.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:28
verses.text: For this [Arian] heresy began to be after all other heresies, and hath gathered the poisons of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:29
verses.text: As it is written of the Antichrist, that "he opened his mouth to blasphemy against God, to blaspheme His Name, and to make war with His saints," so do they also dishonour the Son of God, and His martyrs have they not spared.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:30
verses.text: Moreover, that which perchance Antichrist will not do, they have falsified the holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 15:31
verses.text: And thus he who saith that Jesus is not the Christ, the same is Antichrist; he who denies the Saviour of the world, denies Jesus; he who denies the Son, denies the Father also, for it is written; "Every one which denieth the Son, denieth the Father likewise".

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:3
verses.text: Ambrose assures Gratian of victory, declaring that it has been foretold in the prophecies of Ezekiel.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:4
verses.text: This hope is further stayed upon the emperor's piety, the former disasters being the punishment of Eastern heresy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:5
verses.text: The book closes with a prayer to God, that He will now show His mercy, and save the army, the land, and the sovereign of the faithful.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:7
verses.text: I must no further detain your Majesty, in this season of preparation for war, and the achievement of victory over the Barbarians.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:8
verses.text: Go forth, sheltered, indeed, under the shield of faith, and girt with the sword of the Spirit; go forth to the victory, promised of old time, and foretold in oracles given by God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:10
verses.text: For Ezekiel, in those far-off days, already prophesied the minishing of our people, and the Gothic wars, saying: "Prophesy, therefore, Son of Man, and say: O Gog, thus saith the Lord—Shalt thou not, in that day when My people Israel shall be established to dwell in peace, rise up and come forth from thy place, from the far north, and many nations with thee, all riders upon horses, a great and mighty gathering, and the valour of many hosts? Yea, go up against my people Israel, as clouds to cover the land, in the last days".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:12
verses.text: That Gog is the Goth, whose coming forth we have already seen, and over whom victory in days to come is promised, according to the word of the Lord: "And they shall spoil them, who had been their despoilers, and plunder them, who had carried off their goods for a prey, saith the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:13
verses.text: And it shall be in that day, that I will give to Gog"—that is, to the Goths—"a place that is famous, for Israel an high-heaped tomb of many men, of men who have made their way to the sea, and it shall reach round about, and close the mouth of the valley, and there [the house of Israel shall] overthrow Gog and all his multitude, and it shall be called the valley of the multitude of Gog: and the house of Israel shall overwhelm them, that the land may be cleansed".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:14
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:15
verses.text: Nor, furthermore, may we doubt, your sacred Majesty, that we, who have undertaken the contest with alien unbelief, shall enjoy the aid of the Catholic Faith that is strong in you.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:16
verses.text: Plainly indeed the reason of God's wrath has been already made manifest, so that belief in the Roman Empire was first overthrown, where faith in God gave way.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:18
verses.text: No desire have I to recount the deaths, tortures, and banishments of confessors, the offices of the faithful made into presents for traitors.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:19
verses.text: Have we not heard, from all along the border,—from Thrace, and through Dacia by the river, Moesia, and all Valeria of the Pannonians,—a mingled tumult of blasphemers preaching and barbarians invading? What profit could neighbours so bloodthirsty bring us, or how could the Roman State be safe with such defenders?  141.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:20
verses.text: Enough, yea, more than enough, Almighty God, have we now atoned for the deaths of confessors, the banishment of priests, and the guilt of wickedness so overweening, by our own blood, our own banishment—sufficiently plain is it that they, who have broken faith, cannot be safe.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:21
verses.text: Turn again, O Lord, and set up the banners of Thy faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:22
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:23
verses.text: No military eagles, no flight of birds, here lead the van of our army, but Thy Name, Lord Jesus, and Thy worship.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:24
verses.text: This is no land of unbelievers, but the land whose custom it is to send forth confessors—Italy; Italy, ofttimes tempted, but never drawn away; Italy, which your Majesty hath long defended, and now again rescued from the barbarian.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:25
verses.text: No wavering mind in our emperor, but faith firm fixed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:26
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book II 16:27
verses.text: Show forth now a plain sign of Thy Majesty, that he who believes Thee to be the true Lord of Hosts, and Captain of the armies of heaven; he who believes that Thou art the true Power and Wisdom of God, no being of time nor of creation, but even as it is written, the eternal Power and Divinity of God, may, upheld by the aid of thy Might Supreme, win the prize of victory for his Faith.
